    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-137970-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>We developed an adversarial machine learning (ML) algorithm that uses large language models (LLMs) to generate novel variants of malicious JavaScript code at scale. We have used the results to improve our detection of malicious JavaScript code in the wild by 10%.</p>
<p>Recently, advancements in the code understanding capabilities of LLMs have raised concerns about criminals using LLMs to generate novel malware. Although LLMs struggle to create malware from scratch, criminals can easily use them to rewrite or obfuscate existing malware, making it harder to detect.</p>
<p>Adversaries have long used common obfuscation techniques and tools to avoid detection. We can easily fingerprint or detect off-the-shelf obfuscation tools because they are well known to defenders and produce changes in a predefined way. However, criminals can prompt LLMs to perform transformations that are much more natural-looking, which makes detecting this malware more challenging.</p>
<p>Furthermore, given enough layers of transformations, many malware classifiers can be fooled into believing that a piece of malicious code is benign. This means that as malware evolves over time, either deliberately for evasion purposes or by happenstance, malware classification performance degrades.</p>
<p>To demonstrate this, we created an algorithm that uses LLMs to rewrite malicious JavaScript code in a step-by-step fashion. We started with a set of rewriting prompts including the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Variable renaming</li>
<li>Dead code insertion</li>
<li>Removing unnecessary whitespace</li>
</ul>
<p>Testing samples of malicious code, we continually applied these rewriting steps to allow us to fool a static analysis model. At each step, we also used a behavior analysis tool to ensure the program’s behavior remained unchanged.</p>
<p>Using this LLM-based rewriting technique, we generated significant reductions in the number of vendors on VirusTotal that detected each sample as malicious.</p>
<p>To defend against this type of LLM-assisted attack, we retrained our malicious JavaScript classifier on tens of thousands of LLM-rewritten samples. Our new malicious JavaScript detector is now deployed in our <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> service. This solution helps better protect Palo Alto Networks customers by detecting thousands of new phishing and malware webpages per week.</p>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/llms/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>LLMs</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/genai/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">GenAI</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-137970-_gnvc93wtdm3s"></a>Background: LLMs for Malware Generation</h2>
<p>In 2023, news outlets published several articles about “evil LLMs” that cybercriminals were touting on the dark web. These evil LLMs (e.g., <a href="https://slashnext.com/blog/wormgpt-the-generative-ai-tool-cybercriminals-are-using-to-launch-business-email-compromise-attacks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WormGPT</a>, <a href="https://abnormalsecurity.com/blog/fraudgpt-malicious-generative-ai" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FraudGPT</a>) claimed to be jailbroken versions of models that attackers could use to generate novel malware, write phishing emails and perform other malicious tasks.</p>
<p>Upon closer examination, these claims were largely unsubstantiated in almost all cases. The evil LLMs’ users complained about broken formatting, limited context windows and overall poor code understanding and generation abilities.</p>
<p>As explained in our <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/ebooks/unit42-threat-frontier" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Threat Frontier report</a> on preparing for emerging AI risks, even closed-source LLMs currently require a significant amount of hand holding to generate any non-trivial malware, limiting their usefulness for attackers.</p>
<p>Instead of generating malware from scratch, we experimented with using LLMs to rewrite existing malware samples to evade detection. This approach was much more feasible and produced results that were more difficult to detect.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137970-_oa59aguky4ac"></a>Attack: Using LLMs to Create Malicious JavaScript Variants</h2>
<p>Our algorithm uses an LLM to iteratively transform malicious JavaScript until it evades detection by tools like <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/benign-append-attacks-iupg/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">IUPG</a> or <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/javascript-based-phishing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PhishingJS</a>, without altering its functionality. We designed this algorithm to create thousands of novel malware variants at scale without any manual hand holding.</p>
<p>We focused on JavaScript because:</p>
<ul>
<li>It is a popular choice for a variety of attacks, from malware to phishing</li>
<li>It is a scripting language that allows for a high degree of <a href="https://medium.com/sessionstack-blog/how-javascript-works-3-types-of-polymorphism-f10ff4992be1" target="_blank" rel="noopener">polymorphism</a> with respect to code implementations</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-137970-_i7suq9ft9e56"></a><strong>Algorithm Overview</strong></h3>
<p>We framed this task as an <a href="https://www.nccoe.nist.gov/ai/adversarial-machine-learning" target="_blank" rel="noopener">adversarial machine learning</a> problem, where the goal is to manipulate the model inputs (in this case, the malicious JavaScript) to produce a desired output (a benign verdict).</p>
<p>We first designed a set of rewriting prompts that instructed an LLM to transform a piece of code in a specific way. For example, this set could include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Variable renaming</li>
<li>String splitting</li>
<li>Dead code insertion</li>
<li>Removing unnecessary whitespace</li>
<li>Alternative reimplementation of a function</li>
</ul>
<p>In Figure 1, we present an example of two specific rewriting instructions, one for dead code insertion and another for variable renaming.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137975" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137975" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137975 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-999718-137970-1.png" alt="A screenshot of a text document displaying programming instructions and examples in a coding environment. The document includes examples of 'dead code insert' and 'var rename' with explanations on how to manipulate code using these methods." width="800" height="363" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-999718-137970-1.png 1732w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-999718-137970-1-786x357.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-999718-137970-1-1542x700.png 1542w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-999718-137970-1-768x349.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-999718-137970-1-1536x697.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137975" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Two examples of rewriting prompts.</figcaption></figure>
<p>We then ran samples of the code through our complete set of rewriting prompts in a <a href="https://www.w3schools.com/dsa/dsa_ref_greedy.php" target="_blank" rel="noopener">greedy algorithm</a>. At each iteration, we tried each remaining rewriting prompt, running the resulting samples through the deep learning model. Then we selected the prompt that gave the greatest reduction in the code’s “malicious” score. We present an example of the overall prompt template in Figure 2.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137977" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137977" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137977 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-2926-137970-2.png" alt="Screenshot showing a document with JavaScript code and explanatory text. The image displays original JavaScript code, a brief explanation of obfuscation, obfuscated JavaScript code, and an instruction to adhere to the following format using ellipses. The code is color-coded in yellow, red, and green. " width="800" height="443" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-2926-137970-2.png 1482w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-2926-137970-2-786x435.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-2926-137970-2-1265x700.png 1265w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-2926-137970-2-768x425.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137977" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. The general prompt template when calling the LLM to perform a rewriting step.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In addition to evaluating the increased stealthiness, we had to ensure the code's malicious functionality remained unchanged. For this, we used our custom <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/malicious-javascript-steals-sensitive-data/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">JavaScript behavior analysis tool</a> to confirm the rewritten script maintained the same set of behaviors and network activity as the original script.</p>
<p>The tool simulates execution of multiple possible execution paths to generate a list of behaviors or actions that the JavaScript could take, including DOM injections, redirects and dynamically executed code. If the LLM produces a rewritten script with different behavior than the original script, we simply discarded that rewritten script.</p>
<p>The full algorithm is as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>Given a malicious JavaScript sample \(s\), a deep learning-based malicious JavaScript detector \(d\) and a set of rewriting prompts \(P\)</li>
<li>While \(P\) is not empty:
<ol>
<li>Run each remaining rewriting prompt in \(P\) on script \(s\) to get new scripts \(S_(new)\)</li>
<li>Run a behavior analysis tool on each script in \(S_{new}\). If behavior is changed, discard the script (remove it from \(S_{new}\))</li>
<li>Run each script in \(S_{new}\) through the model \(d\) to get the malicious score for each script</li>
<li>Select the script in \(S_{new}\) that has the largest score decrease (call this \(s_{new}\)) and remove the selected prompt from \(P\)</li>
<li>Run step 2 again with the new selected script \(s_{new}\)</li>
</ol>
</li>
<li>Output final rewritten script \(s_{new}\)</li>
</ol>
<p>The final output is a new variant of the malicious JavaScript that maintains the same behavior of the original script, while almost always having a much lower malicious score.</p>
<p>When we repeated this process on a few hundred unique malicious JavaScript samples, our algorithm flipped the deep learning model’s verdict from malicious to benign 88% of the time.</p>
<h3><a id="post-137970-_jz0yo9ubndmv"></a><strong>Step-by-Step Example</strong></h3>
<p>The following example demonstrates the LLM-based rewriting process applied to a malicious JavaScript sample.</p>
<p>We started with a sample of real-world malicious JavaScript code shown in Figure 3. This code was from a phishing webpage for credential stealing.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137979" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137979" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137979 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-5910-137970-3.png" alt="Two side-by-side screens displaying programming code, mostly in JavaScript, with a focus on user login functionality. The right screen includes further debugging code and a display area showing a numerical precision score for detecting phishing. " width="1000" height="465" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-5910-137970-3.png 1746w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-5910-137970-3-786x366.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-5910-137970-3-1505x700.png 1505w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-5910-137970-3-768x357.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-5910-137970-3-1536x714.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137979" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Example of JavaScript code from a phishing webpage for credential stealing.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Initially, the score from the baseline version of the phishing deep learning model was very high at nearly 1.0 or 100%. This was because the sample closely reflects the type of malicious JavaScript seen in its training set.</p>
<p>Other security vendors had already detected this script as well. In fact, VirusTotal revealed that 13 vendors produced a malicious verdict as shown in Figure 4.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137981" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137981" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137981 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-9040-137970-4.png" alt="Screenshot of VirusTotal website, displaying security analysis for a file with numerical and community response results, and various anti-virus detections listed. The page layout includes tabs like 'Details', 'Relations', 'Behavior', and 'Community.'" width="1000" height="567" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-9040-137970-4.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-9040-137970-4-776x440.png 776w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-9040-137970-4-1235x700.png 1235w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-9040-137970-4-768x435.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-9040-137970-4-1536x871.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137981" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. VirusTotal results for the original malicious (phishing) JavaScript.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In Figures 5-7, we show how this greedy rewriting algorithm can flip the verdict of both our own deep learning model and other vendors on VirusTotal.</p>
<p>In the first step, the greedy algorithm selected the “minification” prompt, which removed any unnecessary whitespace from the code. This first step resulted in a very slight decrease in the deep learning model’s phishing detection score from 0.99999976 to 0.99843687 as shown in Figure 5.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137983" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137983" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137983 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-12721-137970-5.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer screen displaying code in Python and JavaScript, with a focus on text mining and keyword extraction. The screen also displays a high accuracy score highlighted at the bottom for detecting phishing. A portion of the code is highlighted within a red box. " width="1000" height="402" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-12721-137970-5.png 1739w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-12721-137970-5-786x316.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-12721-137970-5-768x309.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-12721-137970-5-1536x617.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137983" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Greedy rewriting algorithm step 1, minification.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Next, the LLM performed string splitting on selected strings. For example, it split the first URL string from Figure 5 <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">‘hxxp://gantep.edu[.]tr/’</span> as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">‘hxxp://’ + ‘/gantep.edu[.]tr’</span> as shown below in Figure 6. This brought the model’s detection score of the rewritten sample down to roughly 0.91 or 91%.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137985" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137985" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137985 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-15965-137970-6.png" alt="Screenshot displaying code in an IDE with comments, variable definitions, and functions related to obfuscation. The screen also shows a 'Phishing Detection Score' at the bottom. A portion of the code is highlighted within a red box. " width="1000" height="509" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-15965-137970-6.png 1609w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-15965-137970-6-786x400.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-15965-137970-6-1375x700.png 1375w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-15965-137970-6-768x391.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-15965-137970-6-1536x782.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137985" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Greedy rewriting algorithm step 2, string splitting.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Finally, the model performed variable renaming, which renamed the variables in the JavaScript code to new names of the LLM’s choice. For example, it simply renamed the first variable <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">strMainDomain</span> from Figures 5 and 6 to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a</span> in Figure 7. Depending on the <a href="https://www.promptingguide.ai/introduction/settings" target="_blank" rel="noopener">temperature</a> setting, the model could produce more or less random variable names.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137987" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137987" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137987 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-19690-137970-7.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer screen displaying JavaScript developer console output with various code segments. The console is mostly in dark mode with text in white and orange, indicating different types of code and alerts. The screen also displays an accuracy score highlighted at the bottom for detecting phishing. A portion of the code is highlighted within a red box. " width="1000" height="467" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-19690-137970-7.png 1565w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-19690-137970-7-786x367.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-19690-137970-7-1499x700.png 1499w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-19690-137970-7-768x359.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-19690-137970-7-1536x717.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137987" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Greedy rewriting algorithm step 3, variable renaming.</figcaption></figure>
<p>At this point, we had stacked enough transformations on top of each other that the deep learning model no longer detected this script as malicious. The phishing detection score was now 0.007577492, less than 1%. Note that the selected steps, as well as the order of the steps, will vary depending on both the target model and the JavaScript itself.</p>
<p>Furthermore, when we uploaded the newly rewritten script to VirusTotal, no other vendors detected it as malicious either. This was true even after 4 days, as shown in Figure 8. This demonstrates that the attack is transferable from our own deep learning model to other analyzers.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137989" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137989" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137989 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-23145-137970-8.png" alt="Screenshot of VirusTotal displaying an analysis of a file, with tabs like Overview, Details, Relations, and Behavior visible. Various security checks and assessments are shown in the interface, with statuses such as 'Undetected' and names like Avast and BitDefender listed under community results. The last analysis date is highlighted in a red box. " width="1000" height="563" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-23145-137970-8.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-23145-137970-8-781x440.png 781w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-23145-137970-8-1242x700.png 1242w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-23145-137970-8-768x433.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-23145-137970-8-1536x866.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137989" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. VirusTotal results for the rewritten script.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137970-_pzwakmpdv18n"></a>LLM-Based Obfuscation Vs. Off-the-Shelf Tools</h2>
<p>Adversaries have been using common obfuscation techniques to avoid detection long before LLMs existed. These obfuscation techniques can be as simple as the following activities:</p>
<ul>
<li>Manipulation through splitting and subsequent concatenation of strings</li>
<li>Encoding strings</li>
<li>Renaming identifiers</li>
<li>Injecting dead code to make the JavaScript source code harder to comprehend</li>
</ul>
<p>These obfuscation techniques can also be more complex, such as control flow flattening, which makes irreversible structural changes to the original source code. Attackers often use <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://obfuscator.io" target="_blank" rel="noopener">obfuscator.io</a></span>, which is also available as an <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/javascript-obfuscator" target="_blank" rel="noopener">npm package</a> with more than 180,000 weekly downloads, to apply these obfuscation techniques at scale.</p>
<p>However, these off-the-shelf JavaScript obfuscation tools have a drawback compared to LLM-based obfuscation. Since these tools are well known to defenders and produce automated changes in a predefined manner, the results from these tools can be easily fingerprinted and reliably detected.</p>
<p>When compared to off-the-shelf tools, obfuscation from LLM rewrites looks much more natural. Figure 9 shows a comparison of the results using these two methods on the same piece of JavaScript code.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137991" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137991" style="width: 711px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137991 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-26825-137970-9.png" alt="Two side-by-side screenshots comparing &quot;Off-the-shelf tool (Obfuscator.io)&quot; code with &quot;LLM-based Obfuscation&quot; code. Both images display JavaScript code snippets, with the left showing more complex and obscured code, and the right having clearer, commented code for functionality like email modification." width="711" height="275" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137991" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Code snippets as rewritten by <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">obfuscator.io</span> (left) and an LLM (right). The LLM-rewritten script appears much more natural than the script from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">obfuscator.io</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>To further demonstrate this, we used both LLM rewrites and similar obfuscation techniques using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">obfuscator.io</span> on a randomly selected set of JavaScript from our dataset. We then measured the text entropy distribution in the resulting JavaScript code.</p>
<p>Entropy in the source text measures the amount of randomness present in the source code. As seen in Figure 10, the distribution of entropy for the LLM-generated scripts was much closer to the original compared to the tool-generated versions. This indicates how organic LLM-rewritten code can be compared to code rewritten by off-the-shelf tools, providing a further incentive for malicious actors to rely upon LLM rewrites to evade detection.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137993" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137993" style="width: 577px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137993 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-29502-137970-10.png" alt="A box plot depicting 'Entropy' values on the Y-axis for three categories: 'Original', 'LLM Generated', and 'Tool Generated'. The 'Original' category is marked in purple, 'LLM Generated' in green, and 'Tool Generated' in blue. Each category shows variability around the median entropy value, with notable outliers in the 'Tool Generated' category." width="577" height="602" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-29502-137970-10.png 577w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-29502-137970-10-422x440.png 422w" sizes="(max-width: 577px) 100vw, 577px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137993" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Compared to LLM rewrites, tool-based obfuscation is more random and more easily identifiable.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-137970-_uf4px9uut5eg"></a>Defense: Data Augmentation and Model Retraining</h2>
<p>We’ve shown how adversarial machine learning techniques can be applied to rewrite malicious JavaScript code using LLMs. Now let’s explore how to improve the baseline detection model to defend against these sorts of attacks.</p>
<p>One natural approach is to reframe this rewriting process as a <a href="https://www.tensorflow.org/tutorials/images/data_augmentation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">data augmentation</a> technique. To improve model generalization, we can augment the training set by including transformed data, in this case, the LLM-generated samples.</p>
<p>We tested how retraining the deep learning model on these LLM-generated samples would affect real-world detection performance. For this experiment, we collected real-world malicious JavaScript examples from 2021 and earlier, specifically phishing-related JavaScript. We then used these samples as a starting point to create 10,000 unique LLM-rewritten samples.</p>
<p>When we added these samples to our model’s training set and retrained it, we saw a 10% increase in the real-world detection rate on samples from 2022 and later. This is a noticeable increase in performance on future real-world malicious JavaScript samples. Figure 11 presents a visualization of this process.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137995" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137995" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137995 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-32153-137970-11.png" alt="Three screenshots side by side illustrating improved real-world detection coverage using Model Retraining. On the left, 'Original Phishing JavaScript for credential theft' code snippet. In the center, 'Off-the-shelf tool' obfuscation example. On the right, 'LLM-based Obfuscation' code snippet. Arrows show the process flow. In the middle is an icon of nodes representing AI and the text Model Retraining: Improved real-world detection coverage. " width="1000" height="392" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-32153-137970-11.png 1886w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-32153-137970-11-786x308.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-32153-137970-11-1784x700.png 1784w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-32153-137970-11-768x301.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-32153-137970-11-1536x603.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137995" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Retraining on LLM-rewritten samples improves real-world detection results.</figcaption></figure>
<p>One possible explanation for this performance boost is that retraining on these LLM-generated samples might make the deep learning classifier more robust to surface-level changes. This makes the model less perturbed by the changes that malicious code could undergo in the real world.</p>
<h3><a id="post-137970-_jjmreqmbxt8k"></a><strong>Real-World Detections</strong></h3>
<p>Figures 12-14 present examples of real-world detections from the adversarially retrained malicious JavaScript model.</p>
<p>Each of the detected JavaScript samples was not yet seen on VirusTotal at the time of detection in November 2024. In each of these instances, the detected JavaScript is quite similar to some other existing phishing scripts, but with slight modifications.</p>
<p>These modifications include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Obfuscation</li>
<li>Commented code</li>
<li>Renamed variables</li>
<li>Slight differences in functionality</li>
</ul>
<p>In the first example, Figure 12 shows deobfuscated code for stealing webmail login credentials from a <a href="https://developers.cloudflare.com/web3/ipfs-gateway/concepts/ipfs/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Web 3.0 IPFS</a> phishing page hosted at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bafkreihpvn2wkpofobf4ctonbmzty24fr73fzf4jbyiydn3qvke55kywdi[.]ipfs[.]dweb[.]link</span>. The script shown in Figure 12 has several behavioral and syntactical similarities to <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/0c5b6e6e2991aa30ac883bae6d5e2998629cd0e7c83e1ca2e1dc32243d153556" target="_blank" rel="noopener">a phishing script that first appeared in May 2022</a>. However, the older script does not contain Telegram-based exfiltration functionality.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137997" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137997" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137997 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-35779-137970-12.png" alt="Three-panel screenshot showing a webpage labeled 'Webmail' with login fields, a blurred obfuscated script in the center, and a deobfuscated script labeled as 'Password Stealer' on the right. " width="1000" height="472" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-35779-137970-12.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-35779-137970-12-786x371.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-35779-137970-12-1484x700.png 1484w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-35779-137970-12-768x362.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-35779-137970-12-1536x725.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137997" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Screenshot of a phishing page and the corresponding deobfuscated malicious JavaScript that exfiltrates the login credentials to Telegram.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 13 shows JavaScript from a Korean language generic webmail phishing page hosted at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jakang.freewebhostmost[.]com/korea/app.html</span>. The deobfuscated JavaScript exfiltrates phished credentials to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nocodeform[.]io</span>, a legitimate form-hosting platform. The deobfuscated script also shows a Korean language message showing the process of confirming (확인중…) but will ultimately display an unsuccessful login via an HTML-encoded string after the victim clicks the submit button.</p>
<figure id="attachment_137999" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-137999" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-137999 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-40593-137970-13.png" alt="Screenshot showing three sections: the left is a webpage featuring a landscape photo with a form overlay, the middle shows obfuscated script code with one line partially highlighted, and the right displays the deobfuscated version of the script revealing it to be a password stealer." width="1000" height="464" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-40593-137970-13.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-40593-137970-13-786x365.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-40593-137970-13-1509x700.png 1509w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-40593-137970-13-768x356.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-40593-137970-13-1536x713.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-137999" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Screenshot of a Korean phishing page containing malicious JavaScript that exfiltrates phished credentials to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nocodeform[.]io</span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 14 shows a Web 3.0 IPFS phishing page hosted on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ipfs[.]io</span> redirected from <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dub[.]sh/TRVww78?email=<em>[recipient's email address]</em></span>. The page contains highly obfuscated JavaScript that renders a customized background depending on the target's email domain. The script also disables right-clicking to prevent users or researchers from easily inspecting the webpage, although we can still add <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">view-source:</span> at the beginning of the URL to view the webpage's source code.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138001" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138001" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138001 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-46372-137970-14.png" alt="Screenshot collage of three items. On the left, a webpage displaying a security warning with some redactions made, in the center, an obfuscated script, and on the right, a slightly deobfuscated script labeled as a password stealer." width="1000" height="460" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-46372-137970-14.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-46372-137970-14-786x362.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-46372-137970-14-1520x700.png 1520w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-46372-137970-14-768x354.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/word-image-46372-137970-14-1536x707.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138001" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Screenshot of our final phishing page example and associated malicious JavaScript.</figcaption></figure>
<p>These three examples of obfuscated JavaScript are typical of the malicious code from phishing pages we frequently detect with our retrained model.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137970-_e9z6gz637jzu"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>Although LLMs can struggle when it comes to generating novel malware, they excel at rewriting existing malicious code to evade detection. For defenders, this presents both challenges and opportunities.</p>
<p>The scale of new malicious code variants could increase with the help of generative AI. However, we can use the same tactics to rewrite malicious code to help generate training data that can improve the robustness of ML models.</p>
<p>We have used these tactics to develop our new deep learning-based malicious JavaScript detector. We retrained this detector on adversarially generated JavaScript samples, and it is currently running in <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> detecting tens of thousands of JavaScript-based attacks each week. Our ongoing research into AI-based threats will help our defenses remain ahead of evolving attack techniques.</p>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the<a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America Toll-Free: 866.486.4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>EMEA: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>APAC: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-137970-_yq7cee4qiqsn"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p>Examples of recent phishing URLs:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bafkreihpvn2wkpofobf4ctonbmzty24fr73fzf4jbyiydn3qvke55kywdi.ipfs.dweb[.]link</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">jakang.freewebhostmost[.]com/korea/app[.]html</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">dub[.]sh/TRVww78?email=</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ipfs[.]io/ipfs/bafkreihzqku7sygssd6riocrla7wx6dyh5acszguxaob57z4sfzv5x55cq</span></li>
</ul>
<p>SHA256 hashes of malicious JavaScript samples:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">03d3e9c54028780d2ff15c654d7a7e70973453d2fae8bdeebf5d9dbb10ff2eab</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4f1eb707f863265403152a7159f805b5557131c568353b48c013cad9ffb5ae5f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3f0b95f96a8f28631eb9ce6d0f40b47220b44f4892e171ede78ba78bd9e293ef</span></li>
</ul>

<li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/malicious-javascript-steals-sensitive-data/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Why Is an Australian Footballer Collecting My Passwords? The Various Ways Malicious JavaScript Can Steal Your Secrets</a> – Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks</li>
<li><a href="https://slashnext.com/blog/wormgpt-the-generative-ai-tool-cybercriminals-are-using-to-launch-business-email-compromise-attacks/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WormGPT – The Generative AI Tool Cybercriminals Are Using to Launch Business Email Compromise Attacks</a> – SlashNext</li>

</ul>
<p>&nbsp;</p>

data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:tags:credential stealer">Credential stealer</a></li><li role="listitem"><a 			</div> 
              <div class="be__post-nav">
    <a class="prev" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:article-nav:Threat Research Center">

                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/02_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of FrostyGoop malware.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-19T11:00:15+00:00">November 19, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/frostygoop-malware-analysis/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications">
                    <h4 class="post-title">FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/bustleberm/" title="BUSTLEBERM" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:BUSTLEBERM">BUSTLEBERM</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/frostygoop/" title="FrostyGoop" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:FrostyGoop">FrostyGoop</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/go/" title="Go" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:Go">Go</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/frostygoop-malware-analysis/" title="FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:related-resources:FrostyGoop’s Zoom-In: A Closer Look into the Malware Artifacts, Behaviors and Network Communications:read now">

                  </a>
                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/11/05_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of a threat like the Bring Your Own Vulnerable Driver (BYOVD) technique.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript:related-resources:TA Phone Home: EDR Evasion Testing Reveals Extortion Actor&#039;s Toolkit:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-11-01T22:00:12+00:00">November 1, 2024</time></span>

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.6.2' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
